column1: What’s next now Tesla is worth a trillion dollars?
column3: Financially speaking, Tesla is a massive success. The question is what will it do with all that money, wonders Rowan Hooper

column1: Barn owls make mental maps of their surroundings while they are flying
column3: Neurons that help humans make mental maps, called place cells, have now been seen in flying birds for the first time

column1: Smart scheduling for big computing tasks cuts emissions up to a third
column3: We could slash emissions from database backups or long machine-learning tasks by waiting to run them until renewable energy makes up the largest part of the energy mix

column1: COP26: Last seven years warmest on record, says UN climate report
column3: As the COP26 climate summit opens in Glasgow, the UN's World Meteorological Organization says global average temperatures have been 1°C warmer than pre-industrial levels for two decades

column1: Skin patch coated in covid-19 vaccine may work better than injections
column3: Covid-19 vaccines in use today have to be stored at cold temperatures, but a patch covered in tiny plastic spikes coated in a vaccine could provide an alternative

column1: EU drones could drop life rafts to migrants in the Mediterranean Sea
column3: The European Maritime Safety Agency has contracted drone company Tekever to use uncrewed aircraft for search-and-rescue missions

column1: Dogs can pick out individual words when we speak to them
column3: Infants are able to identify individual words in continuous speech, even if they can't understand them – and now it seems dogs can as well

column1: RRS Sir David Attenborough and Boaty McBoatface visit London
column3: A research vessel named after the naturalist and broadcaster has visited London – carrying with it a submersible mischievously named by a public vote

column1: Covid-19 news: Fully vaccinated can still get covid-19 from household
column3: The latest coronavirus news updated every day including coronavirus cases, the latest news, features and interviews from New Scientist and essential information about the covid-19 pandemic

column1: US Army will test its most powerful laser weapon ever next year
column3: Lasers are currently used to shoot down small drones, but a more powerful weapon could take on larger targets

column1: Why has Facebook changed its name to Meta and what is the metaverse?
column3: Facebook has rebranded itself as Meta in an attempt to own the metaverse, a concept for a 3D version of the internet that a number of companies are working on

column1: Tardigrades could survive interstellar travel in extreme hibernation
column3: The microscopic organisms have previously survived exposure to the vacuum of space and are able to hibernate using just 0.01 per cent of their normal energy

column1: Ancient Roman statues discovered during HS2 high-speed railway dig
column3: Two complete statues of a man and a woman, along with other Roman objects, were uncovered by archaeologists working on the planned route of the UK's HS2 high-speed railway

column1: New human species has been named Homo bodoensis - but it may not stick
column3: Researchers who reanalysed ancient fossils say they come from a new group of hominins living in Africa around 600,000 years ago, and so deserve a new species name

column1: Jupiter's Great Red Spot extends far deeper than we realised
column3: We only had a skin-deep look at Jupiter before the Juno spacecraft began orbiting the planet in 2016 and the measurements the NASA mission has taken reveal unexpected information about its deep interior

column1: Can Blue Origin help replace the International Space Station?
column3: Blue Origin is one of a number of firms hoping to build a commercial space station, but it isn't clear any will be ready before the International Space Station reaches the end of its life

column1: Two people suppressed HIV for years while pausing medication
column3: A growing number of cases show that some people with HIV can avoid becoming ill even while pausing their medication, as virus levels in their blood remain low

column1: UK urban areas are home to 250,000 unowned cats
column3: It’s not easy to estimate the number of lost, abandoned or feral cats on UK streets, but with the help of citizen scientists we now have a figure

column1: Why we need to get serious about solving the space junk problem
column3: The overcrowding of low Earth orbit with commercial satellites is a problem for astronomers and the satellites – and it needs urgent international action to solve it

column1: Covid-19 dashboard: Cases, deaths and vaccinations
column3: This interactive dashboard tracks the world’s recorded covid-19 cases and deaths, plus vaccines administered

column1: 6 charts that show what climate change is doing to our planet
column3: As the COP26 summit in Glasgow meets to discuss global action on climate change, atmospheric scientist Betsy Weatherhead explains what the science says about greenhouse gases and global warming

column1: COP26: Why India's 2070 net zero pledge is better news than it sounds
column3: Indian prime minister Narendra Modi said at the COP26 summit that the country will hit net zero emissions by 2070. Although this is later than many other nations, the pledge means that the world's major emitters now all have an end in sight for fossil fuels

column1: Grumpy and aggressive shelter cats become more friendly over time
column3: Some animals can develop problematic behaviours the longer they stay in an animal shelter, but cats tend to become friendlier and less aggressive

column1: Over 100 countries at COP26 pledge to end deforestation by 2030
column3: More than a hundred countries announce the Glasgow Leaders’ Declaration on Forest and Land Use, as £14 billion is committed to fight deforestation

column1: Ships could clean up the ocean by turning marine plastic into fuel
column3: Clearing up marine plastic pollution is energy intensive – but ships could convert the plastic they collect into fuel and create a self-sustaining clean-up operation

column1: COP26 news: World leaders give dire warnings on the summit's first day
column3: After an unpromising start, the COP26 climate summit began with leaders acknowledging the urgency of the problem of climate change and warning that action is needed

column1: Heart rates synchronise if two people get on well during first date
column3: A study of young heterosexual people on blind dates found that those who instantly felt sparks developed synchronised patterns of heart rates and palm sweating

column1: NASA's Curiosity Mars rover tests new way to search for alien life
column3: The search for life on Mars requires complex chemical analysis, which the Curiosity rover has tested for the first time. It didn't find anything, but the technique could be used on other worlds

column1: Brain implants boost ability to think flexibly and shake anxiety
column3: Electrically stimulating a region within the centre of the brain helped people with pre-existing brain implants to adapt to changing goals and improve their well-being, pointing to a method for personalised treatment

column1: Meta's touch-sensitive robotic skin could form part of the metaverse
column3: Researchers at the company formerly known as Facebook have developed a touch-sensitive robotic skin that could introduce a greater sense of reality to the metaverse, its planned online virtual environment

column1: Covid-19 news: Global coronavirus toll hits 5 million recorded deaths
column3: The latest coronavirus news updated every day including coronavirus cases, the latest news, features and interviews from New Scientist and essential information about the covid-19 pandemic

column1: Covid-19 news: US to give vaccines to 5-to-11-year-olds this week
column3: The latest coronavirus news updated every day including coronavirus cases, the latest news, features and interviews from New Scientist and essential information about the covid-19 pandemic

column1: Exercising more often doesn't increase your risk of knee arthritis
column3: Previous research has found conflicting results on a link between exercise and knee arthritis, but now it seems that the amount of physical activity you do has no impact - though more strenuous workouts might

column1: Nursery web spiders woo mates with food wrapped in chemical-laced silk
column3: Chemicals in the silk of male nursery web spiders help them attract a mate when used as gift wrap

column1: Vampire bats that live together share a common gut microbiome
column3: Vampire bats form tight social groups and even share regurgitated food – and doing so means the bats end up with a similar gut microbiome

column1: Vipers evolved either nose or eye horns depending on their habitat
column3: The horns on vipers’ eyes could help camouflage their head in rocky areas or trees, while those with nose horns may blend in better on forest floors

column1: COP26 news: A day of promises on water, methane and fossil fuels
column3: On the second day of COP26, countries made progress on limiting methane emissions, capping oil and gas emissions, and cooperating on water issues that are increasingly urgent

column1: Falling bird numbers mean quieter birdsong in Europe and North America
column3: The natural soundscape of birdsong has probably become quieter in Europe and North America over the past 25 years because of a decline in bird numbers

column1: Air pollution from G20 consumers caused two million deaths in 2010
column3: More than half of premature deaths from air pollution worldwide in 2010 were the result of economic consumption in just 11 G20 countries

column1: COP26: 105 countries pledge to cut methane emissions by 30 per cent
column3: A pledge to cut emissions of the powerful greenhouse gas methane by 30 per cent by 2030 has been hailed as “game-changing” by US president Joe Biden, speaking at the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow.

column1: Scotch whisky-makers rely on peat smoke – but it's a climate concern
column3: The UK’s peatlands store vast amounts of carbon and need protecting – but is that compatible with the traditional use of peat smoke as a flavouring in whisky-making?

column1: COP26: Why India's 2070 net-zero pledge is better news than it sounds
column3: Indian prime minister Narendra Modi said at the COP26 summit that the country will hit net-zero emissions by 2070. Although this is later than many other nations, the pledge means that the world's major emitters now all have an end in sight for fossil fuels

column1: A new kind of brain scan is letting us understand how toddlers think
column3: Technological advances mean that we can finally tackle an age-old question: what's going on in the minds of children?

column1: Red feathers determine which common waxbill is the boss
column3: For a songbird called the common waxbill, dominance isn't governed by body size, intelligence, or even temperament, but by the intensity of the colours in their chest feathers

column1: Dogs may get worse separation anxiety when left alone with another dog
column3: Some dogs will bark and howl when left alone by their owner, but an analysis of video footage shows getting a second dog may make the problem worse

column1: What is it like to be at COP26? Utter chaos, huge queues and FOMO
column3: The global climate summit has had a chaotic start, with delegates struggling to enter the venue and attend meetings, and journalists being told they’d be better off watching online, reports Graham Lawton.

column1: Buying fewer snacks and ready meals could slash US carbon footprint
column3: By comparing the grocery shopping of people in the US to recommended dietary guidelines, researchers found that reducing overconsumption could cut carbon emissions by a similar amount as going vegetarian

column1: Baleen whales eat three times more krill than we thought
column3: Baleen whales are the largest animals on Earth, and they are even hungrier than we had assumed, which has huge implications for marine ecosystems

column1: Einstein's theory of relativity could help stop bank account hackers
column3: Having to hand over your PIN to access your bank account puts you at risk of hackers, but the fact that information can't travel faster than light, as laid out by Albert Einstein, could offer a solution

column1: Bats’ landing styles differ depending on where they roost
column3: An analysis of 35 bat species found in Central America, Bulgaria and China shows that the landing style each species takes is related to the make-up of their roosts

column1: Has COP26 put the world on track for holding global warming to 1.5°C?
column3: One new analysis says that new pledges made at the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow have put the world on track for a 1.9°C future, but experts caution it takes a very optimistic view

column1: COP26 news: Toothless net-zero plans and lack of disability inclusion
column3: Organisational chaos continues at the COP26 climate summit, with disability access issues keeping key players out, while the UK’s net-zero business plans are mostly symbolic

column1: Global CO2 emissions have almost returned to pre-pandemic levels
column3: Global CO2 emissions fell by 5.4 per cent during 2020 because of the pandemic, but they are estimated to have risen by 4.9 per cent this year

column1: Why is Facebook ditching face recognition and will it delete my data?
column3: Users of the social network will have their face data deleted, Facebook's parent company Meta has announced, but it is less clear what will happen with the AI algorithms trained on that data

column1: Covid-19 news: 28 million years of life lost globally to covid

column1: Tiny region of human brain that helps regulate sleep studied at last
column3: Our sleep cycles are thought to be regulated partly by the suprachiasmatic nucleus, a 2mm-wide structure in the brain that has now been imaged for the first time with a brain scanner

column1: Is it true that use of synthetic fertiliser is increasing everywhere?
column3: Frequent reports decrying our ever-growing use of synthetic fertilisers don’t reflect reality and fail to see the bigger picture, writes James Wong

column1: Water-absorbing material inspired by plant roots could power robots
column3: Soft robots could one day be powered by a material that absorbs water to become strong and stiff, mimicking the physics of the cells in plant roots

column1: US astronomers plan $11 billion telescope to picture another Earth
column3: A massive report on priorities for the next decade of US astronomy recommends building a telescope that could one day take a picture of a habitable Earth-like planet

column1: Homo naledi infant skull discovery suggests they buried their dead
column3: The partial skull of a Homo naledi child from around 250,000 years ago has been found in a deep, inaccessible cave – suggesting it was placed there by other H. naledi.

column1: COP26: Countries promise coal phase-out and end to fossil fuel finance
column3: Canada, the UK and US pledge to stop around $18 billion of finance a year to international fossil fuel projects, while Poland and Indonesia agree coal phase-out

column1: Brainless sponges have cells that might be the precursors of neurons
column3: Sponges are arguably the simplest animals and they lack a nervous system, but peculiar cells in their digestive chambers may be evolutionary precursors of neurons

column1: Cutting ammonia emissions may be the best way to reduce air pollution
column3: Emissions of ammonia can lead to tiny particles in the air that damage our health, but many countries have no policies on limiting its release into the atmosphere

column1: COP26 news: Coal phase-out boosts hope for limiting warming to 1.5°C
column3: Dozens of countries pledged to phase out coal and others promised to stop funding fossil fuel projects overseas, which helps put the target of 1.5°C of warming in reach

column1: CRISPR-based 'antibiotic' eliminates dangerous bacterium from the gut
column3: Genetically engineered bacteria armed with CRISPR could help combat antibiotic-resistant infections and also allow doctors to edit people's microbiomes

column1: Electric cars expected to outsell diesel ones in the UK next year
column3: For the first time ever, sales of electric cars are forecast to exceed those of diesel ones in the UK next year, thanks to a fall in up-front prices and improvements in public charging infrastructure

column1: Only 45% of US parents give peanuts to infants despite latest advice
column3: Parents have long avoided giving children peanuts early in their life for fear of making them allergic, but updated US advice published in 2017 recommends early introduction

column1: Drone used in attack on US electrical grid last year, report reveals
column3: A US intelligence report has revealed that a drone was used in an attempt to disable an electrical substation in Pennsylvania last year, in the first known attack of its kind

column1: Covid-19 news: Antiviral drugs cut serious illness risk by nearly 90%
column3: The latest coronavirus news updated every day including coronavirus cases, the latest news, features and interviews from New Scientist and essential information about the covid-19 pandemic

column1: US military offers $50,000 to predict where sensors drift in the ocean
column3: The Forecasting Floats in Turbulence competition, run by the US Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, began with the first drop of a drifting sensor in the Atlantic. The best prediction of where it will end up in 10 days wins the prize

column1: Pluto's dark side revealed by moonlight in pictures from New Horizons
column3: After NASA’s New Horizons mission flew past Pluto in 2015, it turned around and took pictures of the dwarf planet’s back, revealing its moonlit dark side

column1: COP26: Climate summit mood is positive as first week draws to a close
column3: Away from the shiny deals and leaders' speeches, negotations are underway in Glasgow on a decision text for the outcome and key rules on climate action

column1: COP26 news: Daily updates from the global climate summit in Glasgow
column3: The latest news from the COP26 climate summit taking place in Glasgow, UK.

column1: COP26 news: Greta Thunberg leads protest march at Glasgow summit
column3: Youth activists have played a big role in promoting the urgency of acting on climate change, and they showed up in massive numbers at the COP26 summit

column1: Covid-19 vaccine tested with suction technique similar to cupping
column3: Studies in rats suggest a device that applies suction to the skin may make cells take up more vaccine particles and enhance the immune response

column1: Lowest level of the atmosphere getting thicker due to climate change
column3: The lowest level of the atmosphere, called the troposphere, has been growing warmer and gaining thickness at a rate of 53 metres per decade since 2000

column1: Watch first footage of Asia’s long-lost bird, the black-browed babbler
column3: The black-browed babbler had been missing for 172 years before its unexpected rediscovery last year – now we have our first footage of the bird in the wild

column1: Earth may have grown around a rock from an alien star system
column3: Interstellar objects like ‘Oumuamua might pass through our solar system in such high numbers that one could have acted as a seed around which Earth grew

column1: Treating Alzheimer's as having many causes may help us beat it
column3: We have focused on the same suspected cause of Alzheimer's for too long. Thinking of it as resulting from multiple overlapping risk factors gives us an opportunity to fight back

column1: COP26: UK asks world leaders to recognise urgent need for action
column3: Recognising the “urgency of action” needed to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees  is on the UK COP26 presidency’s wish list for the crucial climate summit - but the list doesn't include any detail on when countries need to demonstrate that urgency.

column1: Penis worms had hermit crab-like defence system 530 million years ago
column3: More than half a billion years ago, tiny penis worms had learned to protect themselves by grabbing and living inside snail-like shells, like hermit crabs do today

column1: Satellites find close to 800 methane leaks in past four years

column1: Silk modified to reflect sunlight keeps skin 12.5°C cooler than cotton
column3: Silk has been modified through the addition of nanoparticles to reflect 95 per cent of sunlight, which means the material stays extra cool on a hot day

column1: COP26 news: Obama says world must ‘settle for imperfect compromises’
column3: Consensus on the text of the final COP26 agreement has been hard to come by so far, and former US president Barack Obama today encouraged negotiators to take partial victories

column1: Lost in Space-Time newsletter: Will a twisted universe save cosmology?
column3: A forgotten idea of Albert Einstein’s might be the saviour of cosmology, plus the great man’s (vain) quest to undermine quantum weirdness and the question of why the universe looks “just right” for our existence

column3: The latest coronavirus news updated every day including coronavirus cases, the latest news, features and interviews from New Scientist and essential information about the covid-19 pandemic

column1: Current COP26 climate plans would lead to 2.4°C of global warming
column3: Former US president Barack Obama tells  Glasgow summit we are nowhere near where we need to be yet, as new analysis by Climate Action Tracker says a lack of short-term action is casting a shadow over net zero pledges

column1: Newly recognised octopus species described in south-west Australia
column3: Octopus djinda is caught in fisheries and eaten by people, but has only now been recognised as a separate species from another Australian octopus

column1: We need behaviour change to beat climate crisis, says Patrick Vallance
column3: Speaking at the COP26 summit, the UK's chief scientific adviser says the country must do more to change lifestyles in order to meet its climate goals

column1: A strange barrier is keeping cosmic rays out of the Milky Way’s centre

column1: Marsquakes happen more often during the planet’s northern summer
column3: The NASA Insight lander has measured the frequency of shallow marsquakes and found they are more common when it is summer in Mars’s northern hemisphere

column1: COP26 news: First draft of Glasgow agreement expected today
column3: The key outcome of the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow is known as the cover decision, a draft of which is expected to be published soon. Plus, the UK announced plans to fund nuclear technology

column1: Lost capital city of the Mongol Empire was far bigger than thought
column3: The city, built by the son of Genghis Khan, was once thought to be about one-tenth as big as it actually was

column1: Asian honeybees scream in alarm when giant hornets attack the hive
column3: Asian honeybees produce what has been described as a disturbing scream-like sound when their hive is attacked by giant hornets

column1: First draft of COP26 agreement urges countries to revist their plans
column3: Published early this morning, the first draft of the COP26 cover decision that is due to be agreed this week urges countries to “revisit and strengthen” their 2030 climate plans by the end of 2022.

column1: First draft of COP26 agreement urges countries to revisit their plans

column1: How a universal flu vaccine could prevent the next pandemic
column3: Even now, the risk of a deadly flu pandemic is an ever-present danger. But progress on a universal vaccine could protect us and remove the need for annual jabs

column1: Chimpanzees dislike the smell of death like we do
column3: Some chimpanzees will carry around an infant that did not survive, which made researchers wonder if they are as sensitive to the chemicals that produce odours in dead bodies

column1: Covid-resistant people point way to universal coronavirus vaccine
column3: The discovery that some healthcare workers had pre-existing immunity to covid-19 could lead to vaccines that protect against a much wider range of coronaviruses.

column1: Origins of Japanese and Turkish language family traced back 9000 years

column1: Psilocybin therapy steps closer to credibility with largest trial yet
column3: Promising results from a psilocybin trial suggest that psychedelic therapies for depression could help some – but not all – people who don't respond to conventional antidepressants

column1: New species of UK dinosaur was 8 metres long with a bulbous nose
column3: The Isle of Wight in the UK was once home to an ecosystem rich in dinosaurs, including Brighstoneus simmondsi, an 8-metre-long relative of Iguanodon

column1: COP26: Governments and industry aim for zero-carbon shipping corridors
column3: Governments joined industry leaders to create the Clydebank Declaration, committing to creating zero-carbon corridors along major shipping routes – but big questions on cleaning up a heavily polluting industry remain unresolved

column1: Cats can mentally map their owner’s location from voice alone
column3: In tests with hidden loudspeakers, cats show signs of being surprised when their owner’s voice seemed to quickly teleport from one side of a room to another

column1: COP26 news: Draft text calls for phasing out coal and fossil fuels

column1: Our AI is exposing climate misinformation throughout COP26
column3: Misinformation about climate change is polluting social media. That's why we've built an AI to try to expose and stop it, says Bill Posters

column1: ‘Ghosting’ in casual relationships linked to some personality types
column3: Ceasing contact with a partner abruptly is considered more acceptable by people with the personality traits of Machiavellianism, narcissism and psychopathy, at least in short-term relationships

column1: Medicine must stop using race and ethnicity to interpret test results
column3: Relying on race and ethnicity when interpreting medical test results can harm patients. It must stop, say Layal Liverpool and Jennifer Tsai

column1: COP26: New alliance commits to ending oil and gas extraction
column3: The UK, which is hosting the COP26 climate summit in Glagsow, has not signed up to a new alliance to end oil and gas production, an absence that Oxfam said was disappointing.

column1: Sterile neutrinos could explain dark matter – if we can find them
column3: There are good reasons to think that neutrinos have a shy cousin that could explain dark matter, but searches have so far come up empty, writes Chanda Prescod-Weinstein

column1: Our Human Story newsletter: The patterns of domestication
column3: Why did ancient humans begin to domesticate animals? Plus, a new hominin species has been named – but it may not stick

column1: The People’s Summit: An alternative to COP26 led by activists
column3: In Glasgow, much attention has been paid to the COP26 climate summit but an alternative meeting called the People’s Summit brings together environmental activists and campaigners

column1: Using tools helps you understand language and vice versa
column3: Language and tool use seem to be governed by the same brain region, suggests a study involving an fMRI scanner

column1: Deep-sea rockfish that live to be 200 hint at genes for longevity
column3: Longevity research often focuses on short-lived lab animals like mice – but a study of long-lived rockfish might offer new genetic clues for extending lifespans

column1: New mineral davemaoite discovered inside a diamond from Earth's mantle

column1: Paralysed mice walk again after gel is injected into spinal cord

column1: COP26 news: US-China climate pact is important but largely symbolic
column3: Two huge emitters agreed to work together to limit global warming, but the agreement is largely symbolic, as is an alliance to stop extracting oil and gas which hasn't been signed by the biggest oil and gas producers

column1: A fragment of our moon may be orbiting the sun with Earth
column3: Kamo‘oalewa, an object that orbits the sun along with Earth, is unexpectedly red, leading researchers to suspect it came from the moon

column1: New COP26 draft text adds caveats to fossil fuel subsidies phase-out
column3: Nearly 200 countries are on the verge of agreeing to submit more ambitious 2030 emissions plans next year to put world on track for its 1.5C climate goal, however some of the language in the draft agreement has been watered down

column1: COP26 news: Real progress made but more emissions cuts are needed
column3: Before COP26, the world was on course for 2.7°C of warming – now it’s at 2.4°C, which is a significant improvement. Future summits will need to push further on cutting emissions and funding climate adaptation

column1: Birds in the Amazon are adapting to climate change by getting smaller
column3: An analysis of 77 tropical bird species in the Amazon shows that all of them have shrunk and a third developed longer wings over the past 40 years

column1: The Amazon's pink river dolphin population is in freefall
column3: The population of botos, river dolphins found in the Brazilian Amazon, is declining due to fishing with gill nets and is predicted to fall by at least 95 per cent in less than 50 years

column1: COP26: People from climate-ravaged regions say we need action now
column3: Severe flooding and droughts are displacing people from their homes, and attendees at the COP26 climate summit pushed for action on adaptation to climate change

column1: How worried should we be about covid-19 spreading among wild animals?
column3: Studies in the US have revealed a silent epidemic of human coronavirus in wild white-tailed deer and it could be circulating in other wild animals in other parts of the world

column1: Having impostor syndrome may actually make you better at your job
column3: People who are less confident at work were rated as having better interpersonal skills, suggesting there may be upsides to impostor syndrome

column1: COP26: World agrees to phase-out fossil fuel subsidies and reduce coal

column1: What it’s like negotiating at COP26 as a small island state
column3: After a tough two weeks at the Glasgow summit, climate negotiators from small island nations reflect on their experiences.

column1: Trees are dying at increasing rates in forests across Europe
column3: Annual mortality rates are rising for all major tree species in Europe, which means forests will soak up less carbon and wildfire risks will increase

column3: The population of botos, river dolphins found in the Brazilian Amazon, is declining due to fishing with gill nets and is predicted to fall by at least 95 per cent in less than 50 years

column1: Enigmatic Planet Nine may have been seen by telescope in the 1980s

column1: AI can quickly identify structure of drugs designed for legal highs
column3: Artificial intelligence can quickly identify the chemical structure of new drugs that have similar effects to substances such as cocaine and heroin, but have been designed to evade detection by existing tests

column1: IBM creates largest ever superconducting quantum computer

column1: AI can quickly identify structure of drugs designed for ‘legal highs’
column3: An artificial intelligence can identify designer drugs that have similar effects to substances such as cocaine and heroin, but which can’t be detected by current tests

column1: Clean energy tech needs to be pursued despite the mining it involves
column3: Mining for metals to create batteries and solar panels will come at an environmental cost, but not nearly so dear a price as continuing with fossil fuels

column1: The biggest moons of Uranus may have oceans beneath their icy shells
column3: Uranus’s two biggest moons, Titania and Oberon, may have enough radioactive heat to maintain deep liquid oceans that could be detected by future spacecraft

column1: What difference will the COP26 climate summit make?
column3: Despite last-minute changes, the final agreement made at COP26 still amounts to an important ratcheting up of climate ambition

column1: Some genes in the brain may make 100 different proteins

column1: AI predicts which mammals are most likely to spread covid-19
column3: Water buffalo, Sunda pangolins and mink are among the 540 mammals predicted to be likely to spread the coronavirus based on their biology and where they live

column1: Anti-satellite weapons: Will further tests make space more dangerous?
column3: After the Russian military smashed a defunct satellite, creating a cloud of dangerous debris, other powers may wish to prove they have similar capabilities

column1: Covid-19 news: Hackers targeted labs crucial to UK’s pandemic response
column3: The latest coronavirus news updated every day including coronavirus cases, the latest news, features and interviews from New Scientist and essential information about the covid-19 pandemic

column1: Strobe weapons: What are they, who is using them and do they work?
column3: Belarusian soldiers used flashing lights to daze Polish forces amid a border stand-off last week. Strobe weapons have been claimed to have more serious effects, but evidence is lacking

column1: Pale barn owls in UK and Ireland hint at ancient land bridge
column3: The barn owls of northern Europe are typically dark-feathered, making the pale-feathered barn owls of the UK and Ireland an anomaly - now a study suggests they arrived via an ancient land bridge connecting the area to Iberia

column1: Iodine-powered satellite successfully tested in space for first time
column3: Many satellites use xenon as a propellant to help them change orbit or avoid collisions, but the gas is expensive – now we know iodine provides a cheaper alternative

column1: Donated embryo offers rare glimpse of development after implantation
column3: We know little about human development just after implantation, but an embryo donated by one individual offers a rare look at the process

column1: World's largest mass extinction may have begun with volcanic winter
column3: The end-Permian mass extinction 252 million years ago might have begun when eruptions triggered a volcanic winter

column1: mRNA vaccine against tick bites could help prevent Lyme disease
column3: An mRNA vaccine that causes a red, itchy skin rash in response to bites by ticks may allow them to be removed before they transmit Lyme disease-causing bacteria

column1: Anonymised genomes cannot be linked to faces as previously claimed
column3: In theory, genomes shared anonymously could be linked to people on social media because the DNA can be used to predict facial features, but the risk is vanishingly small

column1: Calls to mental health helplines rose by a third in covid-19 lockdowns
column3: Though calls for mental health services spiked by 35 per cent early in the pandemic, the proportion of people seeking help for suicidal thoughts remained the same as before the covid-19 restrictions were put in place

column1: Cancer cells steal energy-generating parts from immune cells
column3: Cancer cells use tiny tubes to reach out to nearby immune cells and capture their energy-generating mitochondria

column1: Strange quantum effect predicted 30 years ago has now been observed
column3: Pauli blocking, a quantum phenomenon that makes a dense quantum gas suddenly turn transparent, has now been observed in three independent experiments

column1: Analysis of earliest covid-19 cases points to Wuhan market as source
column3: A fresh look at what we know about the first covid-19 cases shows that the earliest known case was in a person who worked at the Huanan Market in Wuhan, which was suspected as the source from the start of the pandemic

column1: Robots can use their own whirring to echolocate and avoid collisions
column3: Instead of using sophisticated sensors to detect their surroundings and navigate safely, drones and robots could listen for reflections of their own mechanical noises

column1: Over three-quarters of the world’s vital carbon stores are unprotected
column3: Ecosystems such as forests and peatlands are vital stores for carbon, but less than a quarter of these areas worldwide have protected status

column1: Covid-19 news: Mask wearing cuts infections by 53 per cent
column3: The latest coronavirus news updated every day including coronavirus cases, the latest news, features and interviews from New Scientist and essential information about the covid-19 pandemic

column1: COP26 could never be a true success without delivering climate justice
column3: To be effective, global action on climate change must be just. That means compensating Indigenous people, but also learning from them, writes Graham Lawton
